comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Irene Bordoni (1895-1953), Broadway musical actress: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ir%c3%a8ne_Bordoni She had been a child performer in France, came to the US in 1912, for her Broadway debut at age 17.

comment.author: 80127273@N00
comment._content: Showing your legs in the '10s?  That's pretty risque.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See books.google.com/books?id=XFnfnKg6BcAC&pg=PA131&l... for Bordoni's biography in Vaudeville, Old & New by Frank Cullen, Florence Hackman, Donald McNeilly. Her debut was November 20, 1912 in Broadway to Paris. The show only ran a few weeks but she became a popular vaudeville performer and clearly had a long career in vaudeville, on Broadway, in films, and even early TV, despite being in plenty of flops along the way!!

comment.author: 92987904@N00
comment._content: Cole Porter mentions her in "You're the Top": ''You're a prize, you're a night at Coney, you're the eyes, of Irene Bordoni." According to Robert Kimball, "Irene Bordoni was the performer who had the biggest impact on Porter because she introduced 'Let's Do It' and that was the song, in 1928, that put him on the map.'' Private Lives "His Cue: Another Opening, Another Show" by Joyce Wadler, New York Times, April 1, 1998
